title: esqLABS R Coding Practice
text:
Welcome
The esqLABS R Coding Standards book establishes guidelines to ensure that scripts are written in a unified manner that promotes readability, reproducibility and comprehension for all team members at esqLABS.
This book introduces esqLABS coding style specifications that must be followed by all esqLABS collaborators when writing R code. It also aims to highlight the most important standard coding style rules and to foster R coding good practices. Additionally, it provides a list of useful R resources organized by topics and a list caveats and common mistakes to avoid.






This book is meant for all R users at esqLABS at apply to all R code written for projects. For development guidelines, please refer to the OSPS-R coding standards

title: 1  esqLABS’ R Style Guide
text:
1.1 Syntax

1.1.1 Naming Conventions
In order to better match the naming conventions used on other software projects within the company, the way names are defined is different from the tidyverse style guide.
The naming style depends on the type of object: 

Variable and function names should use only letters and numbers. Use camelCase to separate words within a name. 
# Good

fitModel <- function(){}

resultsDf <- data.frame()

# Bad

fit_model <- function(){}

ResultsDf <- data.frame()
Class names should use PascalCasing.
True constant variables should use ALL_CAPS casing. 
# Good
CONSTANT_VAR <- 1

# Bad

constant_var <- 1
constantVar <- 1
Use meaningful and understandable names. The code should read as a story and only some well-known abbreviations (such as pk) should be used.
# Good

# Primary key
pk <- 1

# Bad

# Primary key
primary_key <- 1



1.1.2 Spacing
Because it is not explicitly said in the tidyverse guideline and for improved code readability, use the following indentation settings:

Use indentation of 2, 
Use spaces instead of tabs.

title: 1  esqLABS’ R Style Guide
text:
1.2 Functions

1.2.1 return()
Prefer using return() for explicitly returning result, although you can rely on R to implicitly return the result of the last evaluated expression in a function.
